Situation1: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: I sat at my desk, the outline for tomorrow’s mentoring session open on my laptop. My mentees were counting on me to guide them through the final steps before their big project deadline. I’d promised them a thorough, structured session—one that could make all the difference in their confidence and performance. As I reviewed my notes, my phone buzzed with a message from my closest friend: “We’re booking our Hajj tickets tonight. Are you in?” My heart skipped. I’d been saving for years, dreaming of this pilgrimage, and now the opportunity was real. But the session I’d planned was on the same day as the group’s departure. My mentees needed me, but so did my faith. The weight of both expectations pressed on me—my responsibility to share knowledge and support, and my longing to fulfill a sacred duty. I stared at the screen, torn, feeling the pull of both worlds, unsure which path to follow.
